bibl.title: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, June 29, 1925

div1.p: Barber queries Carter on the history of malaria in Virginia. He describes his anti-malaria work and his preparation for a conference, in Rome.

div1.head: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, June 29, 1925
div1.opener:
Malaria
Barber
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Greenwood, Miss. June 29, 1925.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I was delighted to get your letter June 22 and all the
good information it contained.

About the diminution of malaria in the U.S. I was delighted to
get the notes malaria Eastern Virginia following the Civil War and again
following the introduction of tobacco culture. But I am not sure that I get
the full reason for its increase at the time of discontinuing
wheat culture in Virginia and the introduction of tobacco. Did Was this
change associated with an economic depression? Did it coincide with
reconstruction disturbances?

I am enclosing a rough-right-off-the-bat summary
of what I shall try to get together for the Rome meeting on the
subject: The Diminution of Malaria in the U.S. I chose that topic
because I thought it would be of more general interest. I have a hunch
that there will be some discussion on that topic at the Rome meeting. Maybe
Roubeud will be there with his zoo hilic theory. AS you know, he holds
that it is the increased prosperity of domestic animals and their
stables, not of humans and their dwellings that has brought about the
diminution of malaria in Europe.

I will make the paper short and will bring in something
about the present economic status of the cotton plantation renters.
A sentence or two about automobile ownership among them
ought to interest the down-trodden of Europe? My Hayne is now with us
and it will be part of his work to see with his on own eyes
something about the status of laborers here. I do not know any other way
of finding out what they eat, for example.

Yes, we are going on with the work on breeding places.
Would like to get at the bottom of the matter, but may not get so far.
Just back from Stuttgart, Ark. Immense numbers of Anopheles now breeding t
there, apparently more than usual. Of many observations we did not see
one Gambusia in the rice fields, although we found them in pools on the
outside. It has been so dry this spring that fish-containing pools
were probably dry when the well water was brought onto the fields.
We found some very alkaline water breeding heavily. And the species was
now nearly all quad. Seems to be more quads there than in the Louisiana
fields.

The John Scott medal ceremonies were very simple, for us.
Just a bow-and-smile affair-no speech expected. Mine was for the invention
of a method of isolating single microorganisms and of injecting
microorganisms or chemical substances into living cells-work I did many years
ago when I was in Bacteriology. I still use the method for
some of my algal and infusoria injectionsinciations. Dr. Chambers improved the methods
so as to make it more practicable for microdissections, so the prize
of $1000 was divided between us. He was not present at the Commencement-
absent in Europe. Orville Wright was also an awardee but missed his train,
and he was absent. My old friend Dr. Ross Harrison was one of the beneficiar
ries and was there, also a Mr. Norton, inventor of a method of grinding steel
which has made possible the present abundance of automobiles. If we had only
gone in for automobiles instead of microbes! But the most enviable men there
Malaria (Barber)
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
was a Penn Bishop of the Episcopalian church. He has a robe
of Oxford resplendent with horizontal red stripes and he got
a fine hood to go over it. We did not have to wear any special clothes.

I am afraid I cannot get hold of much definite
information based on blood examinations regarding the decrease of malaria in
the U.S. I shall be most glad of any suggestions you can make-you really
ought to be the one to write the paper. Especially I should be glad to
learn of places where there has been an increase or failure to decrease in
malaria. I will continue to collect data on this matter, but have to
get a sort of preliminary anyhow. I shall be most glad of your criticism and
shall refer to your information freely in the paper.
With best wishes to you and Miss. Carter.
div1.closer:
M.A. Barber. Mrs. Barber and I would surely be delighted to stop in and
see
see you on our way to Italy, but do not know what will happen in the
final rush. We will probably leave N.Y. Sept. 19th. I may take my
annual leave, or what is left of it, in Italy and so return about
the second week in November. I should like to see some of the malarious
regions of Italy. I know some of the I.H.B. men who are working there.
And do you suppose we will be able to get any light on the truth or
falsity of the thesis: “An Italian scientist never tells the truth
unless he is drunk”. Maybe Ronald Ross has some new data on this
interesting topic.
